intro: Acaena multifida subsp. canella, commonly known as the New Zealand spinach or mountain spinach, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It is a member of the rose family (Rosaceae) and is characterized by its small, spiny fruits and trifoliate leaves. The plant typically grows in alpine and subalpine regions, thriving in cool, moist environments. Its flowers are usually pink or white, and it produces edible seeds that are often used in traditional Māori cuisine. The plant is also valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological role in supporting local wildlife.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena multifida subsp. canella is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the eastern and southern regions. This subspecies thrives in various habitats, including forest margins, shrublands, and rocky areas. It is commonly associated with the lower and middle altitudes of the Southern Alps. The plant is well adapted to the temperate climate and nutrient-poor soils of its native range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena multifida subsp. canella was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the colonial period. This plant has since become naturalized and is now found in various habitats across the country. It is commonly associated with disturbed soils and open areas. However, it is not considered invasive and has not spread aggressively in the local ecosystem.
